text: How doth the city sit solitary that was full of people! How she has become as a widow! She that was great among the nations and princess among the provinces, how she has become tributary!
speaker: Narrator

text: She weepeth sorely in the night, and her tears are on her cheeks; among all her lovers she hath none to comfort her. All her friends have dealt treacherously with her; they have become her enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah has gone into captivity because of affliction, and because of great servitude. She dwelleth among the heathen, she findeth no rest; all her persecutors overtook her in her straits.
speaker: Narrator

text: The highways of Zion do mourn, because none come to the solemn feasts; all her gates are desolate. Her priests sigh, her virgins are afflicted, and she is in bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her adversaries are the master, her enemies prosper; for the Lord hath afflicted her. For the multitude of her transgressions, her children have gone into captivity before the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the daughter of Zion, all her beauty is departed; her princes have become like harts that find no pasture, and they have gone without strength before the pursuer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerusalem remembered in the days of her affliction and of her miseries all her pleasant things that she had in the days of old. When her people fell into the hand of the enemy and none did help her, the adversaries saw her, and mocked at her Sabbaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerusalem hath grievously sinned; therefore she has become a wanderer. All that honored her despise her, because they have seen her nakedness; yea, she sigheth, and turneth backward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her filthiness is in her skirts; she remembereth not her last end. Therefore she came down wondrously; she had no comforter. “O Lord, behold my affliction, for the enemy hath magnified himself!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The adversary hath spread out his hand upon all her pleasant things; for she hath seen that the heathen entered into her sanctuary, whom Thou didst command that they should not enter into Thy congregation.
speaker: Narrator

text: All her people sigh, they seek bread; they have given their pleasant things for meat to relieve the soul. “See, O Lord, and consider, for I have become vile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Is it nothing to you, all ye that pass by? Behold and see if there be any sorrow like unto my sorrow, which is done unto me, wherewith the Lord hath afflicted me in the day of His fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: From above hath He sent fire into my bones, and it prevaileth against them. He hath spread a net for my feet, He hath turned me back; He hath made me desolate and faint all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The yoke of my transgressions is bound up by His hand; they are wreathed, and come up upon my neck. He hath made my strength to fall; the Lord hath delivered me into their hands, from whom I am not able to rise up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath trodden under foot all my mighty men in the midst of me; He hath called an assembly against me to crush my young men; the Lord hath trodden the virgin, the daughter of Judah, as in a wine press.
speaker: Narrator

text: For these things I weep; mine eye, mine eye runneth down with water, because the Comforter that should relieve my soul is far from me. My children are desolate, because the enemy prevailed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Zion spreadeth forth her hands, and there is none to comfort her. The Lord hath commanded concerning Jacob, that his adversaries should be round about him; Jerusalem is as a menstruous woman among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord is righteous, for I have rebelled against His commandment. Hear, I pray you, all people, and behold my sorrow; my virgins and my young men are gone into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: I called for my lovers, but they deceived me; my priests and mine elders gave up the ghost in the city, while they sought their meat to relieve their souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Behold, O Lord, for I am in distress; my bowels are troubled. Mine heart is turned within me, for I have grievously rebelled. Abroad the sword bereaveth; at home there is as death.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have heard that I sigh; there is none to comfort me. All mine enemies have heard of my trouble; they are glad that Thou hast done it! Thou wilt bring the day that Thou hast proclaimed, and they shall then be like unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let all their wickedness come before Thee, and do unto them as Thou hast done unto me for all my transgressions; for my sighs are many, and my heart is faint.”
speaker: Narrator

text: How the Lord hath covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in His anger, and cast down from heaven unto the earth the beauty of Israel, and remembered not His footstool in the day of His anger!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath swallowed up all the habitations of Jacob, and hath not pitied; He hath thrown down in His wrath the strongholds of the daughter of Judah. He hath brought them down to the ground; He hath polluted the kingdom and the princes thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath cut off in His fierce anger all the horn of Israel. He hath drawn back His right hand from before the enemy, and He burned against Jacob like a flaming fire, which devoureth round about.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath bent His bow like an enemy; He stood with His right hand as an adversary, and slew all that were pleasant to the eye in the tabernacle of the daughter of Zion; He poured out His fury like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was as an enemy; He hath swallowed up Israel, He hath swallowed up all her palaces. He hath destroyed his strongholds, and hath increased in the daughter of Judah mourning and lamentation.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He hath violently taken away His tabernacle, as if it were of a garden; He hath destroyed His places of the assembly. The Lord hath caused the solemn feasts and Sabbaths to be forgotten in Zion, and hath despised in the indignation of His anger the king and the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath cast off His altar; He hath abhorred His sanctuary. He hath given up into the hand of the enemy the walls of her palaces; they have made a noise in the house of the Lord, as in the day of a solemn feast.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath purposed to destroy the wall of the daughter of Zion; He hath stretched out a line, He hath not withdrawn His hand from destroying. Therefore He made the rampart and the wall to lament; they languished together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her gates are sunk into the ground; He hath destroyed and broken her bars. Her king and her princes are among the Gentiles; the law is no more; her prophets also find no vision from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of the daughter of Zion sit upon the ground and keep silence; they have cast up dust upon their heads. They have girded themselves with sackcloth; the virgins of Jerusalem hang down their heads to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eyes do fail with tears, my soul is troubled; my passion is poured upon the earth, because of the destruction of the daughter of my people, because the children and the sucklings swoon in the streets of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They say to their mothers, “Where is corn and wine?” when they swooned as the wounded in the streets of the city, when their soul was poured out into their mothers’ bosom.
speaker: Narrator

text: What thing shall I take to witness for thee? What thing shall I liken to thee, O daughter of Jerusalem? What shall I equal to thee, that I may comfort thee, O virgin daughter of Zion? For thy breach is great like the sea. Who can heal thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy prophets have seen vain and foolish things for thee; and they have not exposed thine iniquity, to return you from captivity, but have seen for thee false burdens and causes of banishment.
speaker: Narrator

text: All that pass by clap their hands at thee; they hiss and wag their head at the daughter of Jerusalem, saying, “Is this the city that men call ‘The perfection of beauty, the joy of the whole earth’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: All thine enemies have opened their mouth against thee; they hiss and gnash their teeth. They say, “We have swallowed her up. Certainly this is the day that we looked for; we have found, we have seen it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath done that which He had devised; He hath fulfilled His word that He had commanded in the days of old. He hath thrown down, and hath not pitied; and He hath caused thine enemy to rejoice over thee; He hath set up the horn of thine adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their heart cried unto the Lord. O wall of the daughter of Zion, let tears run down like a river day and night. Give thyself no rest; let not the apple of thine eye cease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arise, cry out in the night; in the beginning of the watches pour out thine heart like water before the face of the Lord. Lift up thy hands toward Him for the life of thy young children, that faint for hunger on top of every street.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, O Lord, and consider to whom Thou hast done this. Shall the women eat their fruit, their children of a span long? Shall the priest and the prophet be slain in the sanctuary of the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: The young and the old lie on the ground in the streets; my virgins and my young men are fallen by the sword. Thou hast slain them in the day of Thine anger; Thou hast killed and not pitied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast called as in a solemn day my terrors round about, so that in the day of the Lord’S anger none escaped nor remained; those that I have swaddled and brought up hath mine enemy consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the man that hath seen affliction by the rod of His wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath led me, and brought me into darkness, but not into light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely against me is He turned; He turneth His hand against me all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: My flesh and my skin hath He made old; He hath broken my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath builded against me, and compassed me with gall and travail.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath set me in dark places, as they that are dead of old.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath hedged me about, that I cannot get out; He hath made my chain heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also when I cry and shout, He shutteth out my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath enclosed my ways with hewn stone; He hath made my paths crooked.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was unto me as a bear lying in wait, and as a lion in secret places.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath turned aside my ways, and pulled me in pieces; He hath made me desolate.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath bent His bow, and set me as a mark for the arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath caused the arrows of His quiver to enter into my reins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was a derision to all my people, and their song all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath filled me with bitterness; He hath made me drunken with wormwood.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath also broken my teeth with gravel stones; He hath covered me with ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Thou hast removed my soul far off from peace; I forgot prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, “My strength and my hope are perished from the Lord,”
speaker: Narrator

text: remembering mine affliction and my misery, the wormwood and the gall.
speaker: Narrator

text: My soul hath them still in remembrance, and is humbled in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: This I recall to my mind; therefore have I hope:
speaker: Narrator

text: It is through the Lord’S mercies that we are not consumed, because His compassions fail not.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are new every morning; great is Thy faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord is my portion,” saith my soul, “Therefore will I hope in Him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is good unto them that wait for Him, to the soul that seeketh Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good that a man should both hope and quietly wait for the salvation of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sitteth alone and keepeth silence, because he hath borne it upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He putteth his mouth in the dust; if so it be, there may be hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: He giveth his cheek to him that smiteth him; he is filled full with reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will not cast off for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But though He cause grief, yet will He have compassion according to the multitude of His mercies.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He doth not afflict willingly, nor grieve the children of men.
speaker: Narrator

text: To crush under His feet all the prisoners of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: to turn aside the right of a man before the face of the Most High,
speaker: Narrator

text: to subvert a man in his cause—the Lord approveth not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is he that saith and it cometh to pass, when the Lord commandeth it not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of the mouth of the Most High proceedeth not evil and good?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why then doth a living man complain, a man for the punishment of his sins?
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us search and try our ways, and turn again to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us lift up our heart with our hands unto God in the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have transgressed and have rebelled; Thou hast not pardoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast covered Thyself with anger and persecuted us; Thou hast slain, Thou hast not pitied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast covered Thyself with a cloud, that our prayer should not pass through.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast made us as the offscouring and refuse in the midst of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: All our enemies have opened their mouths against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear and a snare have come upon us, desolation and destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eye runneth down with rivers of water for the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eye trickleth down and ceaseth not, without any intermission,
speaker: Narrator

text: till the Lord look down and behold from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eye affecteth mine heart because of all the daughters of my city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine enemies chased me sorely like a bird, without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have cut off my life in the dungeon, and cast a stone upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Waters flowed over mine head; then I said, “I am cut off!”
speaker: Narrator

text: I called upon Thy name, O Lord, out of the low dungeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast heard my voice: “Hide not Thine ear at my breathing, at my cry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou drewest near in the day that I called upon Thee; Thou saidst, “Fear not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, Thou hast pleaded the causes of my soul; Thou hast redeemed my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, Thou hast seen my wrong; judge Thou my cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast seen all their vengeance and all their imaginings against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast heard their reproach, O Lord, and all their imaginings against me,
speaker: Narrator

text: the lips of those that rose up against me, and their devices against me all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold their sitting down and their rising up; I am their music.
speaker: Narrator

text: Render unto them a recompense, O Lord, according to the work of their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give them sorrow of heart, Thy curse unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Persecute and destroy them in anger from under the heavens of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: How the gold hath become dim! How the most fine gold hath changed! The stones of the sanctuary are poured out at the head of every street.
speaker: Narrator

text: The precious sons of Zion, comparable to fine gold, how they are esteemed as earthen pitchers, the work of the hands of the potter!
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the seamonsters draw out the breast, they give suck to their young ones; but the daughter of my people has become cruel, like the ostriches in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tongue of the sucking child cleaveth to the roof of his mouth for thirst; the young children ask bread, and no man breaketh it unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that fed on delicacies are desolate in the streets; they that were brought up in scarlet embrace dunghills.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the punishment of the iniquity of the daughter of my people is greater than the punishment of the sin of Sodom, that was overthrown as in a moment, and no hands stayed on her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her Nazirites were purer than snow, they were whiter than milk; they were more ruddy in body than rubies, their polishing was of sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now their visage is blacker than coal; they are not known in the streets; their skin cleaveth to their bones, it is withered, it has become like a stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that are slain with the sword are better than they that are slain with hunger; for these pine away, stricken through for want of the fruits of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hands of the pitying women have sodden their own children; they were their meat in the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath accomplished His fury; He hath poured out His fierce anger, and hath kindled a fire in Zion, and it hath devoured the foundations thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: The kings of the earth, and all the inhabitants of the world, would not have believed that the adversary and the enemy should have entered into the gates of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sins of her prophets and the iniquities of her priests, that have shed the blood of the just in the midst of her,
speaker: Narrator

text: they have wandered as blind men in the streets; they have polluted themselves with blood, so that men could not touch their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cried unto them, “Depart ye; it is unclean! Depart, depart, touch not!” When they fled away and wandered, it was said among the heathen, “They shall no more sojourn there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord hath divided them; He will no more regard them; they respected not the persons of the priests, they favored not the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for us, our eyes as yet failed for our vain help: in our watching we have watched for a nation that could not save us.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hunt our steps, that we cannot go in our streets; our end is near, our days are fulfilled, for our end has come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our persecutors are swifter than the eagles of the heavens; they pursued us upon the mountains, they lay in wait for us in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The breath of our nostrils, the anointed of the Lord, was taken in their pits, of whom we said, “Under his shadow we shall live among the heathen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice and be glad, O daughter of Edom, that dwellest in the land of Uz. The cup also shall pass through unto thee; thou shalt be drunken and shalt make thyself naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: The punishment of thine iniquity is accomplished, O daughter of Zion; He will no more carry thee away into captivity. He will visit thine iniquity, O daughter of Edom; He will uncover thy sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, O Lord, what is come upon us; consider, and behold our reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our inheritance is turned to strangers, our houses to aliens.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are orphans and fatherless, our mothers are as widows.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have paid money for water we drink; our wood is sold unto us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our necks are under persecution; we labor and have no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have given the hand to the Egyptians and to the Assyrians to be provided with bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our fathers have sinned, and are no more; and we have borne their iniquities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Servants have ruled over us; there is none that doth deliver us out of their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: We got our bread with the peril of our lives, because of the sword of the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our skin was black like an oven because of the terrible famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They ravished the women in Zion, and the maids in the cities of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Princes are hanged up by their hand; the faces of elders were not honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the young men to grind, and the children fell under the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders have ceased from the gate, the young men from their music.
speaker: Narrator

text: The joy of our heart is ceased; our dance is turned into mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text: The crown is fallen from our head. Woe unto us that we have sinned!
speaker: Narrator

text: For this our heart is faint; for these things our eyes are dim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the mountain of Zion which is desolate, the foxes walk upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou, O Lord, remainest for ever, Thy throne from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why dost Thou forget us for ever, and forsake us so long a time?
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn Thou us unto Thee, O Lord, and we shall be turned! Renew our days as of old!—
speaker: Narrator

text: But Thou hast utterly rejected us; Thou art very wroth against us.
speaker: Narrator
